Scrollytelling Demo

Introduction

Based on Web requestAnimationFrame, using D3.js to show text, image and chart.

Help readers understand the context of the paragraph.Even though the article is very long, we still draw readers attention.

Images Parallax

Scrollytelling transforms a longform story into an interactive experience.Scrolling can move the viewer through different steps or segments of a visualization. These examples replace the stepper with scrolling.

Image transformation based on different heights.This is the simple usage.

Sometimes we have to pay attention to height, height is very important.

If there is too much white space, there will be a lot of unbeautiful blanks.

If the height is not enough, it will not be conducive for users to read the picture information. They will scroll quickly but not sure what they see.

The entire page layout relies on designer and front-end, they must consider the best user experience.

Take the picture on the right as an example. This is the result of election in one city.

Use a scatter plot to show the range of their votes and compare the differences with other candidates in different year.

Because many candidates get below 10%, the 10% interval is drawn as an observation.

With the D3 chart animation, you can see the content in this interval more clearly.

How many candidates are in this range and what is the difference between them.

Special pull out 5% as a reference value.

The dotted line changes are designed to bring out more information

This demo page cannot expose the original data, so it uses fake data as a template for the presentation of the chart.

Maybe this is not be a good way, we can improve in the future.

The original content emphasizes the details of the dotted line, and this design will be done here.

Some developers tend to do hover effects on the chart, but considering the use of mobile devices, we do not recommend.

Scrollytelling should be as simple as possible to make the information clear.
